title-group.article-title: Electrically conductive silicone rubber–steel fibre composites

contrib-group.aff: Department of Chemistry, University of Pune, Pune, India

author-notes.corresp: Anjali A Athawale, Department of Chemistry, University of Pune, Pune 411007, India Email: agbed@chem.unipune.ac.in

abstract.p: Steel fibre–silicone rubber composites were prepared by two-roll mill method. Various weight fractions of fibres ranging from 20 phr (parts per hundred parts of rubber) to 90 phr, with a diameter of 7–8 μm and length of several metres were used and its influence on the surface resistance, physical properties, short-term and dynamic stress–strain properties of the composites were investigated. Addition of steel fibres renders a sharp decrease in resistance from MΩ to ~3–0.1 kΩ with the concentration from 20 phr to 90 phr, respectively. Addition of 20 phr of steel fibres yields composite with a resistance of 5–10 kΩ, other properties being negligibly altered.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Silicone rubber with its unique structure of polyorganosiloxane is known to exhibit certain outstanding characteristics, which makes it suitable for use in the field of chemical resistance, weather resistance, thermal stability, biocompatibility and oxidation resistance. 1
–11 However, silicone rubber is electrically insulating in nature. For the electrical applications, either, intrinsically conductive polymers (ICPs), which are conductive by means of doping mechanism or composites comprised of polymers, conductive fillers can be used. High costs, instability of the material, poor conductivity, tedious processing have restricted the use of ICPs. The composites with conductive fillers show comparatively better and adjustable electrical as well as mechanical properties. 12 Imparting electrical conductivity to silicone polymer extends its application horizons mainly to electromagnetic interference shielding.

Silicone rubber shows transparency to electromagnetic radiations. 13 Addition of conductive fillers can lead to the formation of silicone rubber conductive composites that can be used in antistatic devices, gas and pressure sensors, electrodes and as a shield against electromagnetic radiations to protect the electronic devices. 14
–21 Carbon black or metal powders are often used as conductive fillers, carbon black gives less thermal stability to the composites, also, it retards the curing of silicone rubber when higher conductivity is required. 22 Metal powders when used, need to be added in large amount to maintain the interparticle connectivity in the rubber matrix which affects the mechanical properties of the composite. 23,24

In this work, silicone rubber–steel fibre conducting composites are prepared by conventional two-roll mill mixing method and analysed. Conductivity is achieved without altering much the physical and mechanical properties at an optimum loading of 20 phr. The composites can be easily cured and moulded in any desired shape. The continuous network of steel fibres formed in the rubber polymer matrix renders conductivity to the composite. These composites can be pigmented, which is not the case with carbon, graphite or other conducting polymers. Recycling of steel fibres from the composites is an added advantage.

sec.title: Composites of silicone rubber and steel fibres
sec.p: VMQ (methyl vinyl silicone rubber) from Dow Corning (Mumbai, India) was used as a base polymer with dicumyl peroxide (locally purchased) as a curative. These two were mixed together on an open two–roll mill mixer at room temperature to form a homogeneous mixture. Steel fibres available in the local market with a diameter of 7–8 μm and continuous length measuring few metres were spun and then added slowly in the proportion of 20 phr to 90 phr. The whole blend was rolled on the mill for few minutes, after addition was completed, with a nip gap of 2–4 mm at room temperature.

The composites with different proportions were then compression moulded in a hot press at 160°C for 10 min. Surface resistance, effect of heat ageing on surface resistance, specific gravity, short–term stress–strain properties which include hardness, tensile strength, elongation, tear strength and dynamic stress and strain property such as rebound resilience were tested.

sec.title: Measurement of physical properties
sec.p: American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) standards were followed for majority of the testing. All the test specimens were cured at 160°C for 10 min as the thickness of test specimens were relatively small in a hot compression press with pressure of 10.34 MPa. Some specimens were cut from the already cured sheet, cooled and used after 24 h. 25,26 All the tests were carried out at room temperature except heat ageing.

sec.title: Morphological characterisation
sec.p: Composites with 20 phr and 50 phr of steel fibres were used for scanning electron microscopic (SEM) analysis on JEOL JSM 6360—A SEM analyser. Samples were coated with Pt.

sec.title: Electrical conductivity
sec.p: In rubbers, as surface conductivity is higher than the bulk, 27,28 surface resistance was mea-sured before and after curing the specimens. Resistance after heat ageing of the samples for 100 h at 90°C was also measured using a digital 2-probe multimeter (Meco Instruments, Mumbai, India).

sec.title: Specific gravity
sec.p: Hydrostatic weighing method from ASTM standard D 297–93 was followed for estimating specific gravity—a ratio of mass of a unit volume of composite to mass of a unit volume of water. 29

sec.title: Hardness
sec.p: Shore A method with type-2 durometer Shore A operating stand was used as per ASTM standard D 2240 to measure the hardness. Six-millimetre thick samples were tested on GSE Testing Instrument with indenter of type ‘A’.

sec.title: Tensile strength
sec.p: ASTM standard D-412 was adopted for testing the tensile strength. Dumb-bell shaped specimens with ASTM standard dimensions were punched in a Die-C from moulded sheet of size 150 mm × 150 mm × 2 mm with a single impact stroke punching machine to ensure a smooth cut. Computerised Tensile Testing machine by Star Testing Systems (Mumbai, India) was used for measuring the tensile strength. Five specimens of every composite were used to measure the strength. Two extremes were discarded and the average of remaining three was taken.

sec.title: Tear strength
sec.p: Tear strength was measured with reference to ASTM standard D-624. Specimens with dimensions given in the standard were punched from the sheet of size 150 mm × 150 mm × 2 mm. Punching machine with a single impact stroke in Die-C was used. Tear strength was measured on Star Testing Systems machine.

sec.title: Rebound resilience
sec.p: Impact resilience was measured using ASTM standard D 2632-01. The specimen of 12 mm thickness and 6 mm diameter was used. Instrument used was a Vertical Rebound Resiliometer by ‘The Shore Instrument and Manufacturing Co. Inc’(Mumbai, India).

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The distribution of steel fibres in terms of homogeneity of the matrix was investigated by SEM analysis of the sample. The SEM micrographs depict the same. At 20 phr as shown in Figure 1(a), the formation of continuous network of steel fibres in rubber matrix can be observed. On the other hand, at 50 phr, seen from Figure 1(b), denser distribution pattern is observed. In both the cases, the fibres are seen to be intact with no damage during the formation of composites.

caption.p: Scanning electron microscopic (SEM) images (a) 20 phr and (b) 50 phr steel fibres.

sec.p: Silicone rubber is known for its highly insulating behaviour with resistance of the order of 1015–1016 Ω; however, composite of silicone, by incorporation of just 20 phr of steel fibres, is observed to exhibit a significant drop in resistance of the order of ~1012 Ω, the resistance being ~9 kΩ, hence a conductive composite could be obtained. Further addition of steel fibres upto 90 phr affects the resistance negligibly with the trend being gradual. From Figure 2, it is observed that the curing of the composites further enhances the conductivity. This can be attributed to the compaction of the composites. At 20 phr, it shows a decrease in resistance from 9 to 3 kΩ, while at 90 phr the same is found to change by one order. As 20 phr is sufficient to make the composites conductive, one can work with only this much addition of steel fibres in the rubber. The maximum standard deviation in resistance observed for composites before curing is ±1.58 and after curing it is ±1.01.

caption.p: Effect of steel fibres on electrical conductivity of composites.

sec.p: Apart from this, the conductivity of the composites is seen to be restored even after subjecting the samples to a thermal ageing at 90°C for 100 h. Figure 3 shows the change in the resistance with respect to time of ageing. These results indicate stable behaviour of the conducting composites. The percentage rise in resistance after thermal ageing for 20 phr is 15–16% and for 90 phr is 10–12% with an overall standard deviation of ±1.01.

caption.p: Effect of heat ageing at 90°C on electrical conductivity of composites.

sec.p: Specific gravity as expected is observed to show a continuous rise which can be seen from Figure 4(a). The steel fibres being a heavier constituent, the specific gravity at 20 phr is ~1.2 which increases to 1.9 at 90 phr, respectively.

caption.p: Effect of steel fibres on (a) specific gravity and (b) hardness of the composites.

sec.p: Hardness of rubber is a resistance to indentation. Figure 4(b) indicates almost similar trend for hardness as that of specific gravity of the composites. The viscoelastic nature of rubber which is responsible for the hardness, 30 changes with higher and higher proportions of steel fibres as they are denser and occupy the major region in the composites. The indenter, which is a calibrated spring needle that deforms the material for a short period while testing the hardness, cannot deform steel fibres. Thus, a continuous rise is observed in hardness. The maximum standard deviation observed for hardness is ±1.51.

Another important property which is affected in case of composite of silicone with 20 phr of steel fibres in comparison to the bare silicone rubber is the tensile strength. Tensile strength is the maximum tensile stress that a substance can withstand till the point of rupture which is contributed by every component in the composite. 31,32

Figure 5(a) shows the variation in the tensile strength with respect to fraction of steel fibres added. The tensile strength shows a drop with 20 phr steel fibres, addition of 30–90 phr show no further drop in the tensile strength, the standard deviation in this case is ±1.00. Steel fibres and silicone rubber are exactly opposite in tackiness, malleability and ductility which are the cause of observed trend in tensile strength and second, there is no bonding between rubber and steel fibres as any dry bond system is not added to the composite. However, the cured composites remain intact in solvents.

caption.p: Effect of steel fibres on (a) tensile strength and (b) elongation at break of the composites.

sec.p: Elongation is the stress applied for stretching the material 33 and is dependent on the elastic nature of the material. From Figure 5(b), the decreasing trend with increasing amount of steel fibres observed in the elongation of the composites from 20 phr to 90 phr can be understood with a standard deviation of ±35.

How a tear can be initiated or propagated is very important in case of rubbers. Figure 6(a) shows the effect of steel fibres on tear strength. Tear strength is expected to increase with higher loadings of steel fibres and the results show the same. The load required to tear same thickness of specimen was observed to be higher. Fibres prevent the material from tearing. With 20 phr loading the tear strength drops by ~3 kN m−1 and steadily increases to ~26 kN m−1 which is higher than the blank specimen, and the maximum standard deviation being ±0.60.

caption.p: Effect of steel fibres on (a) tear strength and (b) rebound resilience of the composites.

sec.p: The ratio of energy output to energy input, on rapid recovery of a deformed specimen can be determined through measurement of resilience of the substance. The percentage rebound measured is inversely proportional to the hysteretic loss. As shown in Figure 6(b), with 20 phr of steel fibres the hysteretic loss is considerably high as the energy output by steel fibres is low compared to the blank specimen. It remains constant for higher proportions of steel fibres as the energy loss due to steel fibres is almost the same. Apart from this, as the hardness increases the resilience decreases, so also the elastic behaviour. 34

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Silicone rubber–steel fibre composites attain very good conductivity at all loading levels above 20 phr. At this concentration of steel fibres, the composite gains conductivity without altering the other properties to a major extent. Hardness and specific gravity shows a linear rise in graph, tear strength is also seen to be enhanced with the concentration, whereas the tensile and rebound resilience exhibit an initial drop followed by a steady value with increasing concentration. At optimum concentration of steel fibres, that is 20 phr, the overall properties are least affected yet the composite becomes electrically conductive.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: Authors are thankful to K.D. Joshi Rubber Industries Pvt. Ltd, Pune, for providing the facilities, Head, Department of Chemistry, University of Pune for the support to the project and Department of Physics, University of Pune for SEM analysis.
